citeinfo.origin: Harvard Map Collection, Harvard College Library
citeinfo.title: Athens, Greece, 1920 (Image 3 of 4) (Raster Image)

pubinfo.publish: Harvard Map Collection, Harvard College Library

descript.abstract: This layer is a georeferenced raster image of the historic paper map entitled: Athenai kai sinoikismoi :klimax 1:8000, oiadepote anatyposis apagoreuetai. It was published by Ekdotikos Chartographikos Oikos K. Gregoura in [1920]. Scale 1:8,000. Covers the Athens, Greece region. This layer is image 3 of 4 total images of the four sheet source map, representing the northeast portion of the map. The image inside the map neatline is georeferenced to the surface of the earth and fit to the Greek Geodetic Reference System (also called the Greek Grid). All map collar and inset information is also available as part of the raster image, including any inset maps, profiles, statistical tables, directories, text, illustrations, index maps, legends, or other information associated with the principal map.This map shows features such as roads, railroads, drainage, built-up areas, selected buildings, historic sites and points of interest, parks, and more. Relief is shown by hachures, contours, and spot heights. Includes legend and inset. Map in Greek. This layer is part of a selection of digitally scanned and georeferenced historic maps from The Harvard Map Collection as part of the Imaging the Urban Environment project. Maps selected for this project represent major urban areas and cities of the world, at various time periods. These maps typically portray both natural and manmade features at a large scale. The selection represents a range of regions, originators, ground condition dates, scales, and purposes.
descript.purpose: Historic paper maps can provide an excellent view of the changes that have occurred in the cultural and physical landscape. The wide range of information provided on these maps make them useful in the study of historic geography, and urban and rural land use change. As this map has been georeferenced, it can be used in a GIS as a source or background layer in conjunction with other GIS data.

attracc.attraccr: The georeferenced raster is a faithfully reproduced digital image of the original source map. Some differences may be detected between the source graphic used and the raster image due to the RGB values assigned that particular color. The intent is to recreate those colors as near as possible.

dataqual.complete: Data completeness for raster digital image files reflect content of the source graphic. Features may have been eliminated or generalized on the source graphic due to scale and legibility constraints

horizpa.horizpar: The horizontal positional accuracy of a raster image is approximately the same as the accuracy of the published source map. The lack of a greater accuracy is largely the result of the inaccuracies with the original measurements and possible distortions in the original paper map document. There may also be errors introduced during the digitizing and georeferencing process. For instance, this raster image was georeferenced to another georeferenced image, which may have its own positional inaccuracies (see "Process Steps"). In most cases, however, errors in the raster image are small compared with sources of error in the original map graphic. The RMS error for this map is 31.50306 meters. This value describes how consistent the transformation is between the different control points (links). The RMS error is only an assessment of the accuracy of the transformation.

citeinfo.title: Athenai kai sinoikismoi :klimax 1:8000, oiadepote anatyposis apagoreuetai.
citeinfo.othercit: 1 map in 4 sheets: col.; 162 x 116 cm., each sheet 95 x 64 cm.Sheet 3

procstep.procdesc: Production of this raster image began with the scanning of the paper map on a high-resolution scanner: (Betterlight, Super8K2 scanning back camera and ViewFinder 5.x capture software). Maps were photographed at a copy stand. A vacuum easel was used to keep the maps flat during photography. The imaging specification was designed to produce detailed "Archival Master" images that, to the extent possible, are faithful reproductions of the originals, and that allow for highly detailed screen reproduction and print reproduction at up 1:1. Images in this collection were processed using Adobe Photoshop. Color and tonal corrections were made using Adobe Photoshop. Image files were viewed on a calibrated monitor. Editing was performed in an ISO 3664 compliant proofing environment. Master Image files were corrected and archived as TIFF files in the sRGB IEC611966-2.1 color-space. When possible files were batch processed using an "action" script derived from edits applied to match a representative sample.

Using ArcMap 9.2 software, the digital TIFF image was georeferenced to common points located on the following scanned, georeferenced paper map(s): Athinai-Piraievs [Sheet] 133, Athinai-Koropion [Sheet] 134, Athinai-Elevsis [Sheet] 150, and Kifisia [Sheet] 151. These sheets were published in 1987 by the Greek Ministry of Agriculture, Directorates of Forest as part of their 1:50,000 scale "Soil Map of Greece" series. The sheet(s) was (were) scanned at 300 dpi and then georeferenced to the four corner latitude, longitude tic marks in the Greek Geodetic Reference System (also called the Greek Grid). The RMS error for the georeferenced sheets are as follows: Sheet 133 (3.98682 meters), Sheet 134 (14.73389 meters), Sheet 150 (20.56251 meters) and Sheet 151 (3.92162 meters). A world file (.tfwx) and an .aux.xml file were automatically generated and saved in association with the digital TIFF image. See 'Horizontal Accuracy' for the RMS error of this specific TIFF.Please note that while the image is stored in Greek Grid coordinates, the projection will need to be defined by the user in order to display the image with other projected data and the world file will need to be stored in the same root directory as the image.

overview.eaover: The indexes reference a color palette of RGB values from 0 through 255, representing the color value from the original paper sheet map. The colors on that sheet can represent relief, drainage, vegetation, populated places, cultural features, coastal hydrography, transportation features (roads, railroads, tracks and trails), spot elevations and boundaries. The colors are sometimes explained in a legend that is incorporated into the map inset or collar.
